title: Siagro+
text:
Estadisticas de la actividad agropecuaria, desarrollo rural, seguridad alimentaria y nutricional y cambio climÃ¡tico de CentroamÃ©rica y MÃ©xico
El Sistema de InformaciÃ³n Agropecuaria (SIAGRO) contiene informaciÃ³n de variables de la actividad agropecuaria, desarrollo rural, seguridad alimentaria y variables climÃ¡ticas. Considera once paÃ­ses en su cobertura geogrÃ¡fica: Belice, Costa Rica, Cuba, El Salvador, Guatemala, HaitÃ­, Honduras, MÃ©xico, Nicaragua, PanamÃ¡ y RepÃºblica Dominicana, y contiene datos anuales y mensuales. SIAGRO es impulsado por la Unidad de Desarrollo AgrÃ­cola y Cambio ClimÃ¡tico en la Sede Subregional en MÃ©xico de la CEPAL. La informaciÃ³n se origina en la CEPAL o en otras bases de datos de agencias asociadas, y cada indicador tiene una explicaciÃ³n de su fuente y metadatos.


Statistics on agricultural activity, rural development, food and nutritional security and climate change in Central America and Mexico
The Agricultural Information System (SIAGRO) contains information on agricultural activity, rural development, food security and climate variables. It covers eleven countries: Belize, Costa Rica, Cuba, The Dominican Republic, El Salvador, Guatemala, Haiti, Honduras, Mexico, Nicaragua and Panama, and contains annual and monthly data. SIAGRO is maintained by the Agricultural Development and Climate Change Unit at ECLACâ€™s Subregional Headquarters in Mexico. The information originates from either ECLAC or other partner agency databases, and each indicator comes with an explanation of its source and metadata.

title: Agricultural activities
text:
Agricultural activity refers to the economic aspects of agriculture and includes data on production, prices, international trade, cultivation and yields, exchange rates, economic activity and public spending.
Content content content

title: Rural development
text: Rural development is directly related to agricultural production since people in rural areas often rely more heavily on agriculture. This section includes data on demographics, education, employment and income, housing and public expenditure and investment

title: Climate data
text:
Climatic variables impact directly on agricultural production. This section includes annual and monthly data on temperature and precipitation at a national level.
Las variables climÃ¡ticas inciden directamente en la producciÃ³n agrÃ­cola. Esta secciÃ³n incluye datos anuales y mensuales de temperatura y precipitaciÃ³n a nivel nacional.

title: Food and nutrition security
text: Food and nutrition security refers to not just the supply of food to a population but is also about ensuring availability, stability and access to food. This section contains data on nutritional conditions, availability, access, acceptability, biological utilization and the structural aspects of food and nutrition security.

title: Climate Data Analysis
text:
Climatic variables impact directly on agricultural production. This section provides a comparative analysis of monthly and annual average temperatures (1960-1990).

import pandas as pd import numpy as np import requests from pyecharts.charts import Bar from pyecharts import options as opts from IPython.display import HTML, display

1. æ ¸å¿ƒé…ç½®ï¼šè§£å†³ GitHub Pages HTTPS ç¯å¢ƒä¸‹çš„åŠ è½½é—®é¢˜
from pyecharts.globals import CurrentConfig CurrentConfig.ONLINE_HOST = â€œhttps://assets.pyecharts.org/assets/v5/â€


2. æ•°æ®è·å–
def get_data(): url = â€œhttps://api-cepalstat.cepal.org/cepalstat/api/v1/indicator/4470/data/enâ€ try: r = requests.get(url, timeout=30) df = pd.DataFrame(r.json()[â€˜bodyâ€™][â€˜dataâ€™]) df[â€˜valueâ€™] = pd.to_numeric(df[â€˜valueâ€™], errors=â€˜coerceâ€™) return df except: return pd.DataFrame()
df = get_data()


æœˆä»½æ’åºé¡ºåº
month_order = [â€˜Januaryâ€™, â€˜Februaryâ€™, â€˜Marchâ€™, â€˜Aprilâ€™, â€˜Mayâ€™, â€˜Juneâ€™, â€˜Julyâ€™, â€˜Augustâ€™, â€˜Septemberâ€™, â€˜Octoberâ€™, â€˜Novemberâ€™, â€˜Decemberâ€™]
if not df.empty: # ç­›é€‰ 1960-1990 æ—¶æœŸ (å¯¹åº”ä»£ç  85163) target_period = â€œ85163â€ df_filtered = df[df[â€˜dim_85162â€™] == target_period].copy() if df_filtered.empty: df_filtered = df.copy()
# è·å–åœ°åŒºåˆ—è¡¨å¹¶å¾ªç¯æ¸²æŸ“
target_col = 'Subnational administrative division'
locations = sorted(df_filtered[target_col].unique())

for loc in locations:
    sub = df_filtered[df_filtered[target_col] == loc].copy()
    # èšåˆæ¯ä¸ªæœˆçš„æ•°æ®
    monthly_avg = sub.groupby('Months')['value'].mean().reindex(month_order).reset_index()
    
    # ç»˜åˆ¶æŸ±çŠ¶å›¾
    bar = Bar(init_opts=opts.InitOpts(width="100%", height="450px"))
    bar.add_xaxis(month_order)
    bar.add_yaxis("Avg Temperature", monthly_avg['value'].round(2).tolist(), color="#1f77b4")
    bar.set_global_opts(
        title_opts=opts.TitleOpts(title=f"Monthly Average Temp - {loc}"),
        yaxis_opts=opts.AxisOpts(name="Temperature (Â°C)"),
        tooltip_opts=opts.TooltipOpts(trigger="axis")
    )
    
    # --- å…³é”®ï¼šä½¿ç”¨ Quarto è¯­æ³•ç”Ÿæˆå­é€‰é¡¹å¡æ ‡é¢˜ ---
    print(f'### {loc}')
    # è¾“å‡ºå›¾è¡¨åµŒå…¥ä»£ç 
    print(bar.render_embed())
else: print(â€œError: Could not retrieve data from API.â€)
